resources.string: Your personal guardian app for women\'s safety
SheShield empowers and protects you. Let\'s start your journey toward safety and peace of mind.
Tailor SheShield to your preferences, choosing the features that matter most.
Be more independent and feel the happiness
Join our community of strong women, access resources, and stand together for safety and empowerment.

You\'re almost there! We sent an email to %s

Just click on the link in that email to complete your signup. If you don\'t see it, you may need to check your spam folder.

You\'re almost there! We sent an email to %s

Just click on the link in that email to reset your password. If you don\'t see it, you may need to check your spam folder.
Access a wealth of safety resources

In recent years, we\'ve witnessed a surge in incidents targeting women, children, and the elderly. These atrocities have grown increasingly alarming, urging us to seek a solution. Introducing SheGuard, our innovative response to these challenges.\n\nSheGuard empowers you by putting your safety back into your hands. We\'ve developed a comprehensive SMS Alert system that keeps your family and friends informed during times of distress.
Experience seamless navigation through our app, designed with the principles of material design, ensuring both functionality and aesthetics.
Join our community swiftly with our hassle-free, multi-option registration process. Your safety is just moments away.
SheShield provides you with an instant lifeline. A simple press of the SOS button sends automated SMS alerts to your selected contacts, including your precise location.
Please sign in to your account first
Create your account and start your journey
Send SOS when you shake your phone. This requires accelerometer sensor.
Use SMS service to send SOS. Carrier charges may apply.
Use Notification service to send SOS. Your contacts must have account.
Play fake police siren at full volume in emergency mode.
Automatically call national emergency service in emergency mode.
Are you sure you want to remove this contact?
Please enter a valid phone number
Password must contain at least 8 characters, 1 digit, 1 lower case letter, 1 upper case letter and no white spaces
Stay alert and scan your surroundings while walking or traveling.
Prefer well-lit, busy paths and avoid isolated shortcuts.
Share your live location with someone you trust when entering unfamiliar areas.
Keep your phone charged and emergency numbers ready for one-tap calling.
Maintain distance from anyone who makes you uncomfortable—step away immediately.
Avoid loud headphones and keep your hands free to stay aware.
Note exit points and safe spots when entering buildings, cabs, or public places.
Avoid sharing personal details like home address or daily routine with strangers.
Verify cab number plate and driver photo before getting in.
Lock your house, hotel room, or vehicle immediately after entering.
If you feel followed, move into a busy store or public area instead of going home.
Use loud noise or SOS alarms to attract attention during danger.
Use simple self-defense techniques aimed at eyes, nose, or knees to escape.
Keep a coded message or safe word ready to alert trusted contacts silently.
Do not follow strangers offering help—ask for directions verbally instead.
Record audio/video discreetly when feeling unsafe and move toward people.
Stick close to women or families in lifts, buses, or isolated places.
Never leave your drink unattended at parties—carry it with you.
Avoid posting live locations online; share updates only after leaving.
Check new rooms or rented spaces for hidden cameras or suspicious devices.
Trust your instincts. If something feels unsafe, act immediately.
Identify safe spots in your area, like open shops or public spaces, where you can quickly move if you feel unsafe.
Always keep your phone charged and your GPS enabled when traveling alone.
Keep important documents, some cash, and a spare key hidden and easy to access if you ever need to leave quickly.
During tense situations at home, move to rooms with multiple exits and avoid dangerous areas like kitchens.
Use silent signals—like emojis, code words, or missed calls—to alert trusted people when you’re in danger.
If safe, maintain a discreet record of threatening or abusive incidents for future action.
Stay connected with local women’s helplines, neighbors, or support groups who can assist you quickly.
Trust your instincts—leave immediately if a situation feels unsafe or unpredictable.
Plan an emergency exit route from your home and practice it mentally for quick action.
Government helpline number for Violence against women / prevention of child marriage
National helpline center for violence against women
Dosh Unisher Mor Helpdesk for GBV/SRHR/psychosocial support.
Bandhu Social Welfare Society (In collaboration with Ministry of Social Welfare)
Multi sectoral referral and psychosocial support; This is the main helpline number to call and has been/being circulated nationwide.
Immediate services to police and hospitals.
Immediate reports/help for any social problems from enquiring after COVID 19 to child marriage and sexual harassment cases.
Immediate service to victims and links up to relevant agencies: doctors, counselors, lawyers, DNA experts, police officers.
Legal assistance, emergency shelter and mental healthcare.
Psychosocial support as well as guideline for SRHR and legal aspects.
Advices on primary healthcare, SGBV and psychosocial support.
01888066747 (For Chittagong Region, including Cox’s Bazar district)
01869859757 (For Dhaka and rest of the districts)
